title: Oroville dam: California officials 'ignored warnings over risk of collapse'
text:
News Oroville dam: California officials 'ignored warnings over risk of collapse' A damaged spillway with eroded hillside is seen in an aerial photo taken over the Oroville Dam in Oroville, California Michael East 14 February 2017 â€¢ 10:32am 
C alifornia officials were warned over Oroville Dam flood risk , it has emerged, sparking anger among the 180,000 citizens evacuated from the area. 
In 2005, environmentalists warned that there was a considerable risk of the highest dam in the US, the Oroville Dam, failing. 
According to local media reports, the warnings were ignored, leading to the evacuation of 180,000 people over the weekend. 
The dam itself was said to have not been in any danger of failing, but the spillway - the channel that relieves excess water from the reservoir - was eroded as water continually poured down it for 38 hours. Evacuations ordered after Lake Oroville Dam uses emergency spillway 
L arge pieces of concrete were missing from the spillway, which helps to withhold hundreds of billions of gallons of water, making authorities fear a potential breach which could have created a 30-foot-high wave. 
Tens of thousands of people have still not returned to their homes as engineers attempt to rectify the situation, ensuring that the flood risk will never resurface. Many local communities are like ghost towns. 
The panic that ensued from the evacuation warnings led to roads becoming gridlocked as residents feared a potential catastrophe. Watch | Residents evacuated as Oroville dam threatens to collapse 00:37 
G ov Jerry Brown is appealing for emergency funding from President Donald Trump but has not received a response. 
As the evacuees fled from the affected communities on Sunday, Trump tweeted about "the crackdown on illegal criminals" and Stephen Miller's "Great job!" on representing him on "the various Sunday morning shows" but failed to comment on the Dam. A farm is seen partially submerged in flood water near Oroville, California on February 13, 2017. 
"Everyone was running around" Oroville resident Maggie Cabral told CNN. "All of the streets were immediately packed with cars, people in my neighborhood grabbing what they could and running out the door and leaving" 
"I just got a text message and then an alert saying get out as fast as you can and there's fire trucks going up and down our street saying evacuate," said Julie Swift. Watch | Crews attempt to fix Oroville dam while residents are kept away indefinitely 01:30 
R ae Lynn Jones said she received a text telling her to evacuate: "It was pretty stressful to move everything we could in 25 minutes," she said. 
"I think that the warning that was given should have been taken with the utmost seriousness" said Bob Wright, an attorney at Friends of the River. Follow Telegraph News
